projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A briefe ABSTRACT OF THE QVESTION OF PRECEDENCY, BETWEENE ENGLAND and SPAIN.

Occa≈øioned By Sir Henry Nevil Knight, the Queen of Englands Emba≈ø≈øador, and the Emba≈ø≈øadour of Spain at Callys, before Commi≈ø≈øioners appointed by the French King: Who had moved a Treaty of Peace in the two and fortieth yeare of the reigne of the ≈øame Queen, by ROBERT COTTON E≈øquire, at the commandement of the Queens Maje≈øty.
LONDON, Printed by L.N. and R.C. for Thomas Slater, at the ≈øigne of the Swan in Duck lane, Novemb. 24. 1642.

div.head: THE PRECEDENCY OF ENGLAND and SPAIN.

list.item: or a Chri≈øtian Kingdome of the throne Roya ‚Ä¢ .

div.head: precedency of England in re≈øpect of the antiquity of the Kingdome.
div.p: TO ≈øeek before the decay of the Roman Empire th ‚Ä¢ antiquity of any kingdom, it were a meer vanity when as the kingdoms of Chri≈øtendome, now in being, had their ri≈øing from the fall thereof; at which in≈øtant Vortigeras, a native of this I≈øle, fir ‚Ä¢ t e≈øtabli≈øhed here a free kingdom 450. years, from whence her Maje≈øty is in de≈øcent Lineally.
And it is plain, that as we were later than Spain reduced under the Roman yoke, ≈øo were we ≈øooner freed from it.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spain.
div.p: Spain, ≈øince the di≈ø≈øolution of the Roman Empire, articuled no King till of late.

For Attala ‚Ä¢ icus (from whom they would upon ≈ølender warrant ground their di≈øcent) was never ≈øtiled Rex Hi≈øpaniae, but Gotharum. Rodoricus Sanctus pag. 312. And the kingdome of Ca≈øtile, wherein the maine and faire≈øt antiquity of Spaine re≈øted, began not before the yeare of Chri≈øt 1017. whereas they were but Earles of Ca≈øtile before.

So that the kingdom of the Engli≈øh begun (which was alwayes, as Beda ob≈øerves, an Heptarchy) 460. years before Ca≈øtile or Spain.
Precedency of England in re≈øpect of Antiquity of Chri≈øtian Religion.
Jo≈øeph of Aramathea planted Chri≈øtian Religion immediatly after the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt in this Realme.
And Ari≈øtobulus, one of them mentioned by S. Paul, Rom. 16.Baronius. Dorothorus Beda. Beda. Baro. & Donaco Con≈øtantini. was Epi≈øcopus Britannorum, and ≈øo likewi≈øe was Simon Zelotus.
The fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King in Europe was Lucius Sirius.

The fir≈øt that ever advanced Papacy of Rome was the Emperour Con≈øtantius, born at York, of whom in the Roman Lawes neer his time is written, Qui Veneranda Chri≈øtianorum fide Romanorum immi≈øit Imperium. And to him particularly more than to other Emperours are the≈øe Epithetary attributed, Divus divae memoriae, divinae memoriae, orbis l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ erator, quietus fundator, reipublicae in≈øtaurator, publicae libertatis a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ magnu ‚Ä¢ , maximus invectus re≈øtitutor urbis Romae, atque orbis.

And there have been more Kings and Princes of the bloud Royall Confe≈ø≈øors and Martyrs in England, than in any Province in Europe: And from Ethelbert King of Kent (converted in anno 596.) untill this day Chri≈øtianity hath been without interruption continued.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spain.
div.p: In the time of Claudius S. James preached in Spain; but gained only nine ≈øoules: So did he in Ireland, (as Vincentius ≈øaith) and they cannot count Chri≈øtian Religion to be then planted in Spain, which ≈øhortly after was fir≈øt tainted with the here≈øie of Pri≈øilian, then with Gothi≈øh Ariani≈øm, and after defaced with Moori≈øh Mahometi≈øm from 707. yeares after Chri≈øt, in continuance 770. years, until Ferdinando King of Aragon and Ca≈øtile utterly expelled the Moores from thence.

div.head: Precedency of England in re≈øpect of the more ab≈øolute authority politicall.
div.p: The Queen of Englands power is ab≈øolute in acknowledging no Superiour, nor inva≈ø≈øalage to Pope nor Emperor. For that ≈øubjection, which by King John was made to Innocentius the third, after in Parliament, Per praeceptum Domini Papae ≈øeptimo Julii cum fidelitate homagii relaxatur omnino.

Sir Thomas Moore in his Debellation ≈øaith, The Church of Rome can ≈øhew no ≈øuch deed of ≈øubjection, neither that the King could grant it of him≈øelfe. And Eugubinus in his Defence of Con≈øtantius Donat. nameth not England, where hee reciteth all the feodary Kingdoms to the Papacy.

Ex legibus Canat.The Peter-pence were not duties, but Eleemozynae Regis, neither the Roman Scot, but Regis largae benignitatis parem non habet Rex Angliae in regno ≈øuo multo fortius, nec ≈øuperiorem habere debet, ≈øaith Bracton.

p.hi: Ip≈øe non debet e≈ø≈øe ≈øub homine, ≈øed ≈øub Deo, & habet tantum ≈øuperiorem Judicem Deum.

div.p: Likewi≈øe in appointing Magi≈øtrates, pardoning life, appeales granting priviledges, taking homage, and the like. And this Jura maje≈øtatis not limited in ≈øen≈øu numerato, bello Judicando, pace ineundo.
Eulentherius the Pope, 1400. yeares ago, in his Epi≈øtles to Lucius King of Brittaine, ≈øtileth him Vicarius Dei in regno ≈øuo.

So is the King of England in Edgars Laws; and Baldus the Lawyer ≈øaith, Rex Angliae e≈øt Monarcha in Regno ≈øuo: and Malmesbury, po≈øt conver≈øionem ad fidem, tot & tantos obtinuit libertates quot Imperator Imperio.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spaine.
div.p: The King of Spaine hath no Kingdome, but is Feodary, as Ca≈øtilia enthralled by Oath of ≈øubjection and Va≈ø≈øaledge from King Henry to Charles the fifth of France, 1369. ex foedore con ‚Ä¢ racto: And for the Netherlands there is due to the French King, or the Papacy; as Aragon to Innocentius the third by Peter, 1204. confirmed by Ferdinando and Alphon≈øus, 1445. and from James by the like Oath, 1453.
And to Sardinia and Cor≈øica the Kings of Aragon from the Bi≈øhops of Rome were under Oath of ≈øubjection inve≈øted ex formali fiducia.
The Kingdome of Portugal in va≈ø≈øall ‚Ä¢ ge to the Pope under an Annuall tribute.

And the Canaries, He≈øperides, and Gorgon Ilands ≈øubjected to the Sea of Rome under the chiefe Rent of foure hundred Florens by Lewis King of Spain, 1243. of both the Indies, Alexander did re≈øerve the regalities of Scicilia to the Church, as chiefe Lord.
And Grando and Navar were made Feodary to the Pope under Julius the ≈øecond.

Naples at every change ≈øendeth a Palphery, as an Heriot due to the Church of Rome; and of the Empire hee holdeth the Dukedome of Millain: So that it is que≈øtionable among Civilians, whether he be Princeps, which holdeth in foedo all, of others; his ab≈øolute authority re≈øtrained in Aragon by Ju≈øtitia Aragonica; in Bi≈øca and other places, by particular re≈øervations; and his Jura Maje≈øtatis in ≈øen≈øu numerato,
bello judicando, pace ineundo, &c. limited by the priviledge of the State, as in Braband, and el≈øe-where in his Spani≈øh territories, ex propriis con≈øtitutionibis & privilegiis.

div.head: Precedency of England in re≈øpect of more ab≈øolute Authority Eccle≈øia≈øticall.
div.p: Her Maje≈øties power is more ab≈øolute in this, confirmed by ancient cu≈øtome and priviledge more than any other Chri≈øtian Prince, for no Legat de latere in England de Jure allowed but the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, if any be admitted by curte≈øie, hee hath no authority to hold plea in the Realme contrary to the Laws thereof. Placit 2. H. 4. And before hee was admitted, and entred the Realme, he was to take oath to do nothing dirogatory to the King and his Councell, placit. an. 1. H. 7. No man might denounce the Popes Excommunication, nor obey his authority, on paine to forfeit all his goods without a≈ø≈øent of the King or his Councell, placit. 32. & 33. Edw. 1.Malmsb. Dun≈øt. Rot.

Henry the fir≈øt called a Provinciall Councell; and ≈øo did Canutus and others: No appeale to Rome without the Kings licence, an. 32. & 34. Edw. 1. Inve≈øture of Bi≈øhops and Church-men in the Kings hand, ex Matth. Paris, & Hen. Huntington. De gratis Pontific. Dunel. placit, 32, Edw. 1, and in 32. Edw. 3. where the rea≈øon of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall authority to ≈øu≈øpend or be≈øtow Church livings, is yeelded, Quia Angliae unguntur in Capite.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spain.
div.p: The King of Spain can pr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ribe no cu≈øtome to prohibite the Popes Leg ‚Ä¢ te, nor u≈øeth any authority penall over the Clergie.

Spaine can produce no example of any Provinciall Councell by call of their King. Bodin. lib. 1. cap, 2. towards the end, writeth that the Kings of Spain, Non ≈øine magna mercede impetrarunt ≈øexti pontificis Romani re≈øcriptione peregrinis ≈øacerdocia tribuerentur.
Appeales from the King to Rome allowed, ≈øo the Kings of Spaine hath no power Eccle≈øia≈øticall, having di≈øpoiled them≈øelves of all, by inthralling their kingdomes to the Church of Rome.

div.head: Precedency of England in re≈øpect of eminency of Royall dignity.
div.p: The Kings of England are appointed as the Kings of France, who only have their preheminency before other Kingdomes, declared by miracle in the cure of the Regis morbus, which they can effect onely, and that of antiquity; from Edw. the Confe≈ø≈øor, who lived in an. 1067. who healed many.

Beda. lib. 2. They are ≈øuperiour Lords of the Kingdoms of Scotland and Man, and Vicarii Imperii, as Edw. 3. and O≈øwold intitled him Rex Chri≈øtiani≈øsimus. They are filii adoptionis Eccle≈øiae; as the Emperour is filius primogenitus, and the King of France, filius natu minor. They are accounted among Reges ≈øuperillu≈øtres, in this Order, Imperator Rex Franciae, Rex Angliae & Franciae. Vido Cor≈øet.

England in the generall Councels at Con≈øtance and Pi≈øa was made a nation, when all Chri≈øtianity was divided into foure Nations, Italicam, Gallicam, Germanicam & Anglicam, ex lib. Sacrarum Ceremoniarum Eccle≈øiae Romanae; Whereupon a ≈øeat accordingly was allowed at the three Generall Councels (viz.) Con≈øtance, Pi≈øa, and Sienna, to the Engli≈øh Emba≈ø≈øadour, next to the Emperour on the left hand, to the King of France on the right hand, which were ancient them≈øelves, before the Spaniards at Bra≈øill, 1431. began to contend for precedency, where it was in the fir≈øt Se≈ø≈øion ordered, that all Legats ≈øhould hold ≈øuch places as they had enjoyed then before, according to their worth and antiquity, yet in the common Councell of Trent, the precedency of France with Spaine was made que≈øtionable.

Augu≈øtus de Carallis, as the ≈øtronge≈øt rea≈øon to bar the French intere≈øt, inferred the Queene of England from her Ance≈øtors, both in re≈øpect of inheritance, conque≈øt and gift, de Jure Queene of France; by which rea≈øon, when he doth ≈øhake or overthrow, as he doth con≈øequently the precedency of England.

And at a treaty betweene Hen. 7. and Philip of Ca≈øtile, 1506. the Commi≈ø≈øioners of England did ≈øub≈øigne before the others, and in the Treaty of Mariage with Queene Mary, an. 1533. tho≈øe of England are fir≈øt rehear≈øed, and at Burburgh, an. 1588. they gave it to her Maje≈øties Emba≈ø≈øadors.

And in re≈øpect of the eminency of this Royall throne to the Sea of Canterbury was granted by Urbane at the Councell of Claremount, an. 1096. for ever the ≈øeat in Generall Councell at the Popes right foot, who at that time uttered the≈øe words, Includamus in Orbe no≈øtro tanquam alterius orbis Pontificem maximum.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spain.
div.p:
1 The Kings of Ca≈øtile are never anointed, neither hath the Spani≈øh Throne that vertue to endue the King therein, and be inve≈øted with the power to heale the Kings-evill; for into France doe yearely
come multitudes of Spaniards to bee healed thereof.
2. No Kingdome held in Fee of him.
3. Spaine at the ≈øaid Councell not remembred one of the Sonnes of the Church.
4. The King of Spaine placed la≈øt after the King of England, Inter≈øuperillu≈øtres by the ≈øaid Cor≈øetus.
5. The Kingdome of Spaine then compri≈øed under Italica natio, and no Nation of it ≈øelfe, as in old time it was called Iberia minor, as a member of Italy, England being Britannia major.
At which time the Spaniard contented him≈øelfe with the place next the King of France.
Precedency of England before Spaine, in re≈øpect of Nobility of bloud.

Her Maje≈øty in lineall de≈øcent is deducted from Chri≈øtian Princes for 800. yeares by Ethelbert a Chri≈øtian, 596. and the matches of her progenitors have been mo≈øt Royall with France, Germanie, Spaine, Scotland and others.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spaine.
div.p: For their antiquitie of De≈øcent as Kings of Spaine, is chiefly from the Earles of Ca≈øtilia, about 500. yeares ≈øince; for they cannot warrant their de≈øcent from Attalaricus the Goth, and as Dukes of Au≈øtria from the Earles of Hab≈øpurgh, only about 300 yeares ≈øince.
Their matches anciently for the mo≈øt part were with their ≈øubjects, and of late in their owne bloud.
Precedencie of England in re≈øpect of antiquity of Government.
Her Maje≈øtie having reigned now mo≈øt happily about 42. yeares.

This we would not at this time have alledged, but that the Spani≈øh Emba≈ø≈øador at Ba≈øil objected, in this re≈øpect, the minority of King Hen. 6. Her ≈øex herein is nothing prejudiciall, when as both divine and humane Lawes do allow it, and accordingly Spaine, England and Hungaria, in≈øomuch, that Mary the la≈øt Queene was alwayes ≈øtiled Regina Maria Hungariae.

div.head: Sub≈øequence of Spaine.
div.p: The King of Spaine is yet in the infancie of his kingdome.
For the precedency may be viz. the antiquity of the Kingdome, when as Ca≈øtile, Aragon, Navarre, and Portugall, had their fir≈øt Kings about 1025.

The ancient receiving of the Chri≈øtian Faith by Jo≈øeph of Arimathea,
Simon Zelotus, Ari≈øtobulus, yea, by S. Peter, and by S. Paul, as Theodoretus and Sophrinius do te≈øtifie. This kingdome was held of God above, and in no Va≈ø≈øallage to the Emperor or Pope, as Naples, Sicilia, Aragon, Sardinia, and Cor≈øica.

Sir Thomas Moore denieth that King John either did or would make England ≈øubject to the Pope, and that the tribute was not paid (pag. 296.) but the Peter pence were paied to the Pope by King John by way of almes. The ab≈øolute power of the King of England within other Kingdomes is much re≈øtrained. England is accounted the fourth part of Chri≈øtendome. For in the Councell of Con≈øtance all Chri≈øtianity was divided into foure Nations, as afore≈øaid, and accordingly gave their voyces. England in the opinion of the Pope is preferred, becau≈øe it is contained in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall divi≈øion. Two large Provinces which had their Legati nati, when as France had ≈øcantly one. The Emperor is accounted Major filius Papae. The King of France is Filius minor. The King of England Filius adoptinis. The Archbi≈øhops of Canterbury are accounted by the Pope‚ñ™ Tanquam alterius orbis Papae, and appointed to have places in Generall Councels at the Popes right foot.
The title of Defen≈øor fidei, as honourable and as ju≈øtly be≈øtowed upon the Kings of England, as Chri≈øtiani≈øsimus upon the French, or Catholicus upon the Spaniard.
Edw. the third was created Imp. vicarius perpetuus Imperii cum jure, rite noti≈øque in omnes, 1338.
Imperii ≈øubditi, and the Kings of England Papae vicarii by Pope Nicholas the ≈øecond (viz.) Coporave, 1065.
Innocentius the fourth ≈øaid, Vere hortus delitiarum e≈øt Anglia, vero puteus inexhau≈øtus ubi multa abundant, &c. 1246.
King Hen. 2. elected King of Ieru≈øalem by the Chri≈øtians, 1185.

Richard the fir≈øt conquered the kingdom of Cyprus, and gave it to Guy L ‚Ä¶
who≈øe po≈øterity reigned there untill of late yeares.

This kingdome hath heretofore challenged the ≈øuperioritie over Scotland, as afore≈øaid, and is now at this time the ab≈øolute Lord of Ireland, be≈øides it ≈øtill retaineth the title to the Kingdome of France.
